creator: alvaro.sanchez@salenda.es
text:
Hi,

We have a Grails web application in a production environment, which sometimes get stuck in an infinite loop of StackOverflowError's.

Sample stacktrace:

------------------------------8<------------------------------

GRAVE: El Servlet.service() para servlet grails lanzó una excepción
java.lang.StackOverflowError
  at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationHttpRequest.getAttributeNames(ApplicationHttpRequest.java:243)
  at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationHttpRequest$AttributeNamesEnumerator.<init>(ApplicationHttpRequest.java:906)

[...] hundreds lines [...]

------------------------------8<------------------------------

Taking a look at the last calls before the loop:

GroovyPageWritable.java:262 (http://svn.codehaus.org/grails/trunk/grails/src/web/org/codehaus/groovy/grails/web/pages/GroovyPageWritable.java)

        for (Enumeration attributeEnum =  request.getAttributeNames(); attributeEnum.hasMoreElements();) {


ApplicationHttpRequest.java:243 (http://www.docjar.com/html/api/org/apache/catalina/core/ApplicationHttpRequest.java.html)

  242       public Enumeration getAttributeNames() {
  243           return (new AttributeNamesEnumerator());
  244       }

ApplicationHttpRequest.java:906

  905           public AttributeNamesEnumerator() {
  906               parentEnumeration = getRequest().getAttributeNames();


Line 243 causes an infinite loop of calls, ending in a StackOverflowError

creator: alvaro.sanchez@salenda.es
markt@apache.org
text:
Both issues above have the same root cause. Something somewhere called setRequest() on the wrapped request and passed in the same wrapped request setting up the infinite loop. I've double checked the Tomcat code and it doesn't do this so it looks like either an application issue or a framework issue.

I'd like to throw an IAE if an app does this but unfortunately, the spec doesn't allow it.
